txt: Greenbelt development prioritizes the profits of a handful of private developers over the wellbeing of communities and the environment.
We must keep the greenbelt! Torontonian's & Canada need of the land to grow food and keep contact with nature, Vertical growing is the way.
The farmland currently in the Greenbelt is vital for Ontario’s food security.
We can’t eat pavement or drink concrete. The greenbelt collects and filters our drinking water and is home to our local food supply.
Removing 7,400 acres from the Greenbelt, 83% of which is prime agricultural land, threatens farmers' ability to feed our growing cities.
Once valuable land is removed from the Greenbelt and developed, it's lost forever. Another reason why it should be protected in perpetuity.
or build on all those golf courses scattered about
Democracy is not making back room deals that benefit few and create a more unstable future for the rest!
We must keep the Greenbelt! Torontonians and Canada need the land to grow food and keep contact with nature. Vertical growth is the way.
If there are mistakes in the original demarcation of the Greenbelt, they should be reviewed, e.g  Dr. Tom Nugent's property.
Sprawl created our infrastructure deficit in Hamilton, the provincial government has weakened local democracy and hurt cities financially.
Leave the greenbelt alone. Develop on abandon lots and restore vacant apartments and townhouses in the north end
The Greenbelt protects some of Ontario's best farmland. Protecting the Greenbelt protects food security for Ontario's people.
The Greenbelt sinks climate emissions; promotes foods & water security; fosters biodiversity & connection to nature; improves health.
Ontario can and must build affordable housing within existing urban boundaries without destroying our finite and invaluable farmland.
The greenbelt is not the place for the more affordable housing that is needed. Truly affordable housing can only be built within urban areas
We need stronger legal protections for Greenbelt land.
Citizen deliberation and community consultation should be essential in shaping the Greenbelt's policies.
Shrinking the wetlands in the Greenbelt is dangerous because it will make communities vulnerable to flooding caused by climate change.
I encourage you to join the facebook group “Pickerings Greenbelt and Farmlands Matter” to learn about  the Duffins Rouge AG Preserve
We should be expanding the Greenbelt instead of removing land.
We love the Greenbelt as an area for diversity and protection of nature. Revert the decision and protect it now
We shouldn’t build houses at the expense of destroying our planet
Farmland must be saved from hydro batteries 2.1 million acre policy.
The greenbelt is an invaluable space for farmland as well as an important ecological habitat for our native flora and Fauna
We should build affordable housing outside of greenbelt.
There is increasing demand and the economy is stagnant, we need to open up for development and provide food, homes and jobs.
The greenbelt is protected land and should remain so in perpetuity. The land should forever belong to our decendents and remain biodiversity
Preserving the Greenbelt for future generations should a top priority.
Greenbelt policy needs to be informed by farmers, indigenous leaders, and concerned citizens, not developers and land speculators.
I agree with the commenter who is concerned about the economy, but the answer is not to open up the Greenbelt. So much urban public space.
I feel that Ontario is doing enough to protect the environment and the climate.
The Greenbelt is the source of water for millions of Canadians. The Ont gov has ignored this.
The benefits of opening the Greenbelt outweigh the environmental costs.
We talk abt carbon capture as a climate solution. But wetlands in the green belt are already natural carbon sinks. Do we want to lose that?
We need more housing, but we can build it without opening the Greenbelt.
We must listen to the experts. Whether is be about the environment or the affordable housing issue. They know what they are talking about.
Protection is a priority. Indigenous groups must be in the conversation. There needs to be land stewardship opportunities.
We can and must build affordable housing within existing urban boundaries without destroying our finite and invaluable farmland.
I have never met a farmer who wouldn’t sell his farm for a profit
We should build on all the golf courses scattered about.
To make housing more affordable and cities more livable, we should increase density in already-developed areas, not encourage urban sprawl.
The land needed to build any significant housing already exists within our cities! Urban boundaries is the only thing keeping sprawl at bay.
Protect our greenbelt at all costs
Areas not required for food production and water protection are more difficult to develop, but are an opportunity for interesting housing.
I support Doug Ford's decision to open the Greenbelt.
There should be no development in the Greenbelt. It should be illegal for any party to open it up for housing, roads, manufacturing etc.
Reverse the decision to build highway 413, which will negatively impact the greenbelt's importance to agricultural and environmental
Ban AirBnB and create a tax for residences that are not occupied, follow New York's policy about short term rentals.
Doug Ford’s actions are anti-democratic and show disregard for the autonomy of citizens and municipal governments.
This whole issue is overblown. If the costs of development help ease the living crisis, then so be it.
We should develop brownfield land.
Removing 7,400 acres from the Greenbelt, 83% of which is prime agricultural land, threatens farmers’ ability to feed our growing cities.
I trust the current government to manage the Greenbelt.
The Greenbelt is already home to numerous animals and plants.
As an Ontarian, I'm proud of the Greenbelt.
Greenbelt policy needs to be informed by farmers, Indigenous leaders, and concerned citizens, not developers and land speculators.
Restore Greenbelt land grab. Reverse Bill 23. Reinstate wetland, agriculture, and nature protections. Restore official plans province-wide.
There is absolute certainty that Ontario, and Hamilton, do not need new land to build the housing we need!
We should be densifying on land that's already zoned for housing, instead of building in the Greenbelt.
Carving up the Greenbelt threatens sensitive wetlands, forest, and farmland crucial to mitigating the negative effects of climate change.
The Greenbelt fosters food security, fights climate change, protects us floods & heat waves; preserves water, & promotes biodiversity.
Developers must adhere to transparency laws.
I don't want to subsidize wealthy developers building expensive houses while the cost of food skyrockets. We need to support our farmers.
We have enough land outside the Greenbelt for human homes and don't need to destroy any piece of it!
Not only do we need more homes built within the urban boundary, we need homes that the average Hamiltonian can afford, in the $400,000 range
Test seed
The removal of the Greenbelt lands was only about greed and corruption.
We can develop within existing urban boundaries by looking at vacant and underutilized lots as well as slightly increasing density
We must find a way to further protect the Greenbelt to ensure that attacks like this and attempts to develop it do not happen again
Farmers deserve a  sustainable living so they can feed us.  We need to increase direct connection btwn the urban & rural communities
The Greenbelt provides clean air, fresh water, climate resilience & a reliable local food source to help Ontario thrive - ecology & economy.
We have exactly one chance to get this right: the forests, wetlands and rich farmland of the Greenbelt MUST BE PROTECTED IN PERPETUITY.
We have to protect the Greenbelt even if it's unpopular; some things are more important than democracy.
Agriculture has played an important role in Ontario's history..... environmental, economic, + cultural. Development fractures that.
People don’t want to live in shoeboxes. The townhouses in the north end have sat empty for nearly a decade.
The only way to restore democracy and rebuild the people’s trust is to return the 7,400 acres wrongfully removed from the Greenbelt.
I don't really care about the Greenbelt one way or the other.
We should expand public transit.
Rather than build on the greenbelt, there are rural towns in dire need of services (ex. abattoirs).  Pay attention to our needs too.
Adding density in already-occupied areas will make housing affordable for young people, not creating sprawl in the Greenbelt.
Densification increases property values making housing less affordable.
there's no need to build more of anything, abolish money and this isn't an issue, remove the borders of countries, the earth is everyone's
Any development of the Greenbelt needs to be opened up to community consultation and town halls across the province. It is held in common.
Conduct a fair Greenbelt review. Remove properties with access to municipal services that no longer meet the criteria for Greenbelt zoning.
Building housing is too important to worry about how it impacts the environment.
Decisions were made against the advice of experts, the will of Ontarians & against ethical standards. We can't afford to lose the Greenbelt.
The greenbelt is and always has been protected. It is a diverse eco system that should NEVER be developed. ✌️💚
If land is to be removed from the Greenbelt, it must only be done after an open and democratic process with input from the public
Carving up the Greenbelt threatens sensitive wetlands, forest, and farmland crucial to mitigating the effects of climate change.
Farmers deserve a sustainable living so they can feed us. We need to increase direct connection between the urban and rural communities.
The only way to restore democracy and rebuild the people’s trust is to return the 7,400 acres wrongfully removed from the Greenbelt
The Greenbelt plays a vital role in fostering sustainable development. We must ensure that its management is democratic and inclusive.
As a 75 year old born and raised Hamiltonian, I want the greenbelt to be around for my great-grand kids. Not giant houses they won't afford.
There needs to be a fair Greenbelt Correction Review. Remove justified Greenbelt properties that border urban boundaries/municipal services.
Utilized for more growing spaces, access to land for folks prioritizing land back for our indigenous communities toward food sovereignty.
Mixed density housing within existing boundaries is an evidence-based response to housing needs. The Greenbelt must not be developed.
Removing 7,400 acres from the Greenbelt, 83% of which is prime agricultural land, threatens farmers’ ability to feed our growing cities
At a time when the world is experiencing increasing food insecurity due to changing climate, to pave over Ontario's food basketis criminal.
The greenbelt should be protected as it has a positive environmental impact in Ontario and Canada at large
Hamiltonians should be proud of the leadership role our community has taken in fighting the province's Greenbelt grab.
I love the access we have to green space and local food. It must be protected and supported at all costs.
We should open the Greenbelt to development as long as the process is fair.
The Greenbelt isn't really that important.
We should remove all legal protections from Greenbelt land.
We need new 15 minute communities (where everything you need is within 15 mins of walking), not faux luxury housing on greenbelt lands.
Use the money to redevelop areas that are livable but need a little love. Save the Greenbelt!
This government’s interference regarding our protected Greenbelt is ridiculous!  Broken promises always become a lack of trust ‼️
Urban sprawl isolates us and perpetuates car-dependency. To replace our farmland with this is inexcusable.
Develop brownfield land. Increase public transit. Foster a strong and robust local food economy. Developers must adhere to transparency laws
There should be opportunities for citizens to participate in decision-making processes to protect and enhance shared environmental heritage.
We should foster a strong and robust local food economy.
Ford only cares about paying back favours he received from his wealthy donors & friends, he’s corrupt & a criminal & has to resignev
The Greenbelt needs to be protected and guarded against all urban growth.
I feel confident that the Ontario government is representing the interests of ordinary people in its handling of the Greenbelt.
To restore democracy and rebuild the people’s trust - return the 7,400 acres wrongfully removed from the Greenbelt.
Greenbelt is the most ecologically diverse area in Ontario, containing fragile habitats that support unique, threatened or at-risk species.
The only way to restore democracy and rebuild the people’s trust is to return the 7,400 acres wrongly removed from the Greenbelt.
Leave the Greenbelt alone. Develop on abandoned lots and restore vacant apartments and townhouses in the north end.
We talk about carbon capture as a climate solution, but wetlands in the Greenbelt are already natural carbon sinks. We shouldn't lose that.
Holland marsh drained in the 1930s provides most of our food. The properties that were taken out of the green belt don’t produce any food.
With 10 flooding events in 12 September days one would hope planning decisions would be made looking through the lens of climate change.
The Tin Man was a robot
Agree!
